advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first advert for the Atari 520ST checked against an Apple Mac and an Apricot computer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bradley Sturch</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1983 <br><br> Advert said <br><br><font color="#666666"> Simple Isn't it?. The COMPAQ portable computer can do what the IBM Personal Computer does. To go.<br><br> It runs all the popular programs written for the IBM. It works for the same printers ans other peripherals. It even accepts the same optional expansion electronics that give it additional capabilities and fonctionality.<br><br> There's really only one big difference. The COMPAQ computer is designed to travel.<br> Carry the COMPAQ computer from office to office. Carry it home on the weekend. Or take it on business trips...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRAPPING MAN!</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> A compact problem-solving add for engineers, statisticians, scientists and financial and business analysts. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST +4 SALES, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The personal computer of Mr sales manager"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.sapere.demon.co.uk/computers/honeywell.html" target="_blank">Adrian Wise's website</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL MONITOR AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>It was actually a rebadged Taxan monitor</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gerard Touitou</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>Texas Instruments home computer, simply unbeatable</i> <br><br> Notice that the man seems not to feel at ease with a computer keyboard and still doesn't use the right finger...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles da Silva</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (FEB. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Educatel advert for their correspondance courses using the Microlab system.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 4</strong></font><br><blockquote>These are fake screenshots, that is to say drawn by an artist.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"There music puts in it"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.colors: 10'' monochrome LCD display (non-backlit on early models)
computer.description:
IBM had little luck with it's portable models, and realized to keep up, they needed a laptop. IBM came up with the 5140, it was a laptop that could be converted into a main desktop in seconds.
The LCD screen detaches for a color CRT to be attached. IBM didn't sell many of these due to the fact the LCD was not backlit, and conpetition was less expensive.
The IBM 5140 was available in two models, the 2 and the 22; the only difference being the 22 came with diagnostics software. IBM saw little success from this machine due to high costs, slow processor at 4.77 MHz, hard to read screen, and cumbersome size. Both models were expandable to 640KB RAM with third party upgrades.
This laptop is unique however because it used static memory, instead of dynamic memory. The static memory was more reliable, and gave the CPU 7% more processing power.
There were three distinct display models for the IBM 5140. One was the standard 10? monochrome LCD, which was hard to read. Later on IBM changed this to a super twist LCD, which was much easier to read.
The first CRT option was an IBM 5144 monochrome display, which was easy to read, it came with a stand, ac power cord, and CRT adaptor for the 5140. The second and final option was an IBM 5145 color display, which was easy to read as well, it came with a stand, ac power cord, and CRT adaptor for the 5140. The CRT monitors sat atop a stand which was placed over the 5140, the 5140 then could be slid in and out from under the monitor stand for easy conversion. The LCD screen that attaches via proprietary connection could be disconnected and removed easily with the push of a button.
There is a 72 pin port on the back of the unit for several expansions; serial, parallel, and CRT interfaces were available.
These computers also came with a small, direct-attach thermal printer that was same width, height, etc as the computer so you could carry computer, printer and all by the one handle.
Thanks to Alex Rushing for info and www.computercloset.org for the picture. _______________________

item.description: Convertible printer|||... attached to the back of the computer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CONVERTIBLE PRINTER</strong></font><br><strong>> ... attached to the back of the computer</strong><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.hardwareDescription: SPEECH ADAPTER Word-Sound attachment for use with IBM Writing to Read software. Has 200-word vocabulary or digitally record up to 30 seconds of sound.
computer.name: 5140 Convertible
computer.ports: Parallel interface, CGA video ouput, Serial port, Proprietary Snap-on Port, Expansion bus
